thread.title: Labor takes on wealthy, multinationals

title: Labor takes on wealthy, multinationals
text:
View Photo 

Labor wants Australia's wealthiest people to pay another $2.5 billion a year in tax but has not made a firm commitment to the "roaringly popular" policy. 
Labor leader Bill Shorten will take a tax reform agenda to the next federal election focusing on tax avoidance by the wealthy and multinational companies. 
"It's just that Labor would rather see foreign multinationals pay their fair share than Australians who earn the least paying more GST on the things they need most," Mr Shorten told the opening day of the ALP national conference in Melbourne on Friday. 
The tax reforms include ensuring multinational companies do not shift profits to minimise the tax they pay in Australia. 
Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese talked up the so-called "Warren Buffett rule" that would force the nation's highest income earners to pay at least a minimum rate of tax. 
Creating a Buffett rule in Australia would raise an additional $2.5 billion a year from the top one per cent of income earners, research by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling has found. 
Mr Albanese said ordinary workers were the ones doing the heavy lifting in the tax system. 
"They know that the nurses, the teachers, the miners, the construction workers, they shouldn't be paying all the tax while the millionaires simply are able to minimise theirs," he said. 
Community and Public Sector Union national secretary Nadine Flood said the "roaringly popular" proposal was about ensuring the highest income earners actually paid some tax. 
"If we implement this it will mean that some of our top income earners in this country may be able to rent less helicopters and I reckon that might be a good thing," she said. 
The ALP conference agreed to consider bringing in an Australian version of the "Warren Buffett rule" but stopped short of adopting it as firm policy. 
The rule is named after legendary billionaire investor Warren Buffett, who wrote in 2011 that he thought it was unfair that he pays a lower federal tax rate than his secretary. 
Thinktank The Australia Institute has proposed a Buffett rule that would limit the incentive for very high income earners to use excessive tax deductions, applying a 35 per cent minimum tax rate for those earning above $300,000 per annum. 
Recent Australian Tax Office figures show around 75 Australians earning more than $1 million a year paid no tax. 
Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen pledged that a federal Labor government would keep its election promises in its first budget, even if it means being unpopular. 
"When I deliver Labor's first budget I want to be delivering a program on which we fought and won an election, for which we sought and won a mandate," he told delegates in a speech to the conference.
